questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

 

The combination of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain resulting from arthritis, and urinary findings of hematuria and proteinuria is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and renal abnormalities. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years.

 

The patient may present with the following clinical features:

 

  • Skin lesions- These typically involve the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs, as well as the buttocks.
  • Pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding are examples of abdominal manifestations.
  • Renal manifestations include hematuria, nephritic syndrome, and nephrotic syndrome. Adults have more severe renal manifestations. Some patients develop a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura: typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding, without joint pain or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Dengue fever: Dengue fever is a viral illness that typically presents with fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Churg-Strauss syndrome is a rare systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis, often involving multiple organs. While arthritis may be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, palpable purpura is uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schonlein purpura is characterized by the presence of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement, typically manifesting as hematuria and proteinuria. It is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly affecting children and is distinguished by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in affected tissues.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. His CT scan is given. What could be the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with symptoms including nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. The CT scan shows a mass involving the maxillary sinus. These clinical features are highly suggestive of maxillary sinus carcinoma. This condition often presents with such symptoms due to the tumor mass causing obstruction and local invasion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: This condition typically occurs in adolescent males and arises from the nasopharynx, not the maxillary sinus. It is characterized by severe epistaxis and nasal obstruction, but the patient's age and the location of the mass make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

 

Option C. Orbital Floor Fracture: Orbital floor fractures are best seen in coronal CT views and typically result from trauma. They present with symptoms such as diplopia, enophthalmos, and infraorbital anesthesia, but not with nasal obstruction and cheek swelling without trauma history.

 

Option D. Rhinocerebral Mucormycosis: This condition is seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes. It involves rapid tissue destruction, including the eyes and palate, leading to black necrotic tissue. The presentation of the patient does not fit this severe and aggressive infection.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maxillary sinus carcinoma presents with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. Diagnosis is often confirmed through imaging, showing a mass in the maxillary sinus

questions.text: Neonatal meningitis is caused by? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

Explanation:

 

Neonatal meningitis, which occurs in newborns up to 28 days old, can be caused by various pathogens. The most common cause of neonatal meningitis is Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS). This bacterium is a leading cause of both neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

 

Streptococcus agalactiae is a Group B beta-hemolytic streptococcus and is known for its positive CAMP test and Hippurate hydrolysis test. These tests help in the identification and confirmation of the bacteria.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Group A streptococci: Although Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) can cause various infections, it is not the primary cause of neonatal meningitis.

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: This bacterium is a common cause of meningitis in older children and young adults but is not the primary pathogen in neonatal meningitis.

 

Option D. H. influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae can cause meningitis in children, particularly those aged 2 months to 3 years, but it is not the most common cause in neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of neonatal meningitis is Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus).

 

MC Causes of Acute Pyogenic (bacterial) Meningitis

 

  • Neonates: Group B streptococcus (Str. agalactiae)
  • 2 months to 3 years: Pneumococci > Meningococci > H. influenzae
  • 3 years to 20 years: Meningococci
  • > 20 years: Pneumococci

 

Additional Information

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crown rump length by USG

 

Explanation:

 

Crown-Rump Length (CRL) by Ultrasound:

 

  • The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is by measuring the Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound. This method is reliable as it directly measures the embryo or fetus and provides a precise gestational age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adding 280 days to the Last Menstrual Period (LMP):

 

  • This method, known as Naegele’s rule, is commonly used but assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles or those using contraceptives.
  • It is less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives, which can alter the regularity of menstrual cycles.

 

Option C. Fundus Examination:

 

  • Palpation of the uterine fundus is a physical examination method to estimate gestational age. However, it is less accurate in the first trimester and typically used in the second and third trimesters.

 

Option D. Adding 256 days to the LMP:

 

  • This method is not standard practice and is less commonly used compared to adding 280 days to the LMP.
  • It would be even less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is the measurement of Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page no 475, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome
Chest Xray is the investigation of choice

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding thymoma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most common neoplasm of thymus

 

Thymomas are indeed the most common primary tumors of the thymus. These tumors originate from the epithelial cells of the thymus, an organ located in the anterior mediastinum. While they can be associated with various systemic syndromes, particularly myasthenia gravis, they may also be asymptomatic and are sometimes discovered incidentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Most common posterior mediastinal tumor: This statement is incorrect. Thymomas are tumors of the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior. Neurogenic tumors are the most common tumors in the posterior mediastinum.

 

Option C. Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome: Thymomas can be asymptomatic or they may present with symptoms due to compression of nearby structures. While they can cause symptoms like dyspnea (shortness of breath) if they compress the trachea or lungs, or symptoms of Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome if they compress the SVC, these are not the most common presentations. The association with systemic syndromes like myasthenia gravis is more characteristic.

 

Option D. Chest Xray is the investigation of choice: While a chest X-ray can identify a mediastinal mass suggesting a thymoma, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest is usually the investigation of choice for further characterization and to evaluate the exact size, location, and any local invasion. The CT scan provides more detailed images than a simple chest X-ray.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used for maintenance therapy in opioid abuse? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Buprenorphine

 

Maintenance therapy in opioid dependence involves the use of long-acting opioids to stabilize the patient and prevent withdrawal symptoms, thus helping them gradually reduce dependency on more harmful opioids.

 

Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist that binds to the same receptors as other opioids but with a lower intrinsic activity, meaning it produces less euphoria and has a ceiling effect that reduces the risk of misuse. Additionally, buprenorphine has a long half-life, which makes it suitable for maintenance therapy as it allows for once-daily dosing and reduces withdrawal symptoms.

 

Another common medication used for maintenance therapy is methadone, a full opioid agonist. However, buprenorphine is often preferred due to its safety profile, particularly the lower risk of overdose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to manage symptoms of opioid withdrawal, particularly by reducing sympathetic overactivity (e.g., sweating, agitation, and anxiety). However, it is not used for maintenance therapy but rather for symptom control during detoxification.

 

Option C. Butorphanol: Butorphanol is an opioid analgesic that can be used for pain management. It is not typically used for maintenance therapy in opioid addiction and has potential for misuse.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose. It does not have a role in maintenance therapy but is crucial for emergency management of opioid toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methadone and buprenorphine are long-acting opioids used for maintenance therapy in opioid addiction. They replace the addictive opioid to prevent withdrawal symptoms.
  • To treat withdrawal symptoms:
    • Diazepam (a benzodiazepine) is used for seizures.
    • Clonidine or beta blockers are used for sympathetic symptoms.
  • Naltrexone is used to prevent relapse in opioid addiction.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and aortic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He took 3 NTG tablets with no relief. His vitals are stable and cardiac enzymes were normal. An ECG on admission is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unstable Angina

 

The patient's presentation includes chest pain unrelieved by nitroglycerin (NTG), stable vitals, and normal cardiac enzymes. The provided ECG is normal, showing no signs of ST elevation or ischemic changes such as ST depression or T wave inversion.

 

Unstable Angina involves chest pain at rest or with minimal exertion, and normal cardiac enzymes. The patient has multiple risk factors (dyslipidemia, hypertension, aortic sclerosis), and the fact that his chest pain did not respond to NTG and his enzymes are normal strongly suggests unstable angina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. STEMI: STEMI is characterized by ST elevation on ECG and elevated cardiac enzymes indicating myocardial necrosis. This patient's ECG shows no ST elevation, and his cardiac enzymes are normal, making STEMI unlikely.

 

Option B. NSTEMI: NSTEMI would present with elevated cardiac enzymes due to myocardial damage, despite the absence of ST elevation. This patient’s normal enzyme levels exclude NSTEMI.

 

Option C. Stable Angina: Stable angina presents with chest pain that is typically relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. The patient’s chest pain persisted despite taking NTG, indicating that stable angina is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain that occurs at rest or with minimal exertion, does not respond to nitroglycerin, and is associated with normal cardiac enzyme levels.

choices.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (750/37.5 mg) (2 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (750/37.5 mg) (2 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy from Rajasthan weighing 50 kg is diagnosed with mixed P. vivax and P. falciparum malaria. What is the appropriate treatment regimen on day 2?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

 

In the treatment of malaria, the choice of drugs and regimen depends on the type of malaria (whether it's P. vivax, P. falciparum, or mixed infection) and the geographic location due to different strains' drug resistance profiles. For mixed infections involving P. vivax and P. falciparum, the treatment typically includes a combination of drugs targeting both species.

 

For P. vivax malaria, chloroquine is generally used, followed by primaquine for 14 days to achieve a radical cure by eliminating hypnozoites and preventing relapse. However, in mixed infections and P. falciparum malaria, the treatment regimen includes an Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT). Specifically, in regions like Rajasthan, ACT comprises artesunate plus sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine.

 

On day 2 of treatment, sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (which is given only on day 1) has already been administered, so the treatment continues with artesunate and primaquine.

 

Primaquine is dosed at 0.25 mg/kg for 14 days in cases of P. vivax, and the dosage calculated for this patient (weighing 50 kg) is 15 mg/day

 

(0.25 mg/kg × 50 kg = 12.5 mg, rounded to the nearest available tablet strength).

 

The correct regimen on day 2 includes Artesunate (to continue targeting the malaria parasites) and Primaquine (for radical cure and to prevent relapse), specifically at the dosage of 2.5 mg per tablet (6 tablets totaling 15 mg).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malaria Treatment Regimens:

questions.text: Viral infection causing transient aplastic anemia is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B-19

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection targets erythroid cell lines, particularly the pronormoblast stage, and is known to cause transient aplastic anemia, particularly in patients with underlying hemolytic disorders, as well as other clinical manifestations such as erythema infectiosum, arthritis, and non-immune fetal hydrops.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma
Small cell cancer lung
Large cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented in OPD with hemoptysis. On examination, a hilar mass was noticed. The histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the cells were positive for p40. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

The given clinical history and the histopathological findings showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

Tumor arises in a large bronchus and are prone to massive necrosis and cavitation.

 

The tumor is diagnosed microscopically by identification of either intercellular bridges or keratinization or keratin/squamous pearls.

 

It is positive for p40 and p63 markers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma lung: Generally occurs in the peripheral regions of the lung and is often associated with mutations like KRAS, EGFR, or ALK. Immunohistochemical markers like TTF-1 and Napsin-A would be positive, not p40.

 

Option C. Small cell cancer lung: This type is strongly associated with smoking and typically occurs centrally. However, it is identified by markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56, not p40.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma: This is a diagnosis of exclusion, where the tumor lacks the histological characteristics of other types of lung cancers. It is not associated with p40 positivity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Rickets occurs due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin D

 

  • Rickets is a skeletal disorder that results from a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. 
  • The primary cause of rickets is a lack of Vitamin D, which is essential for the absorption of calcium and phosphate in the body. 
  • Without adequate Vitamin D, bones can become soft and weak.
  • Key features of rickets include:
    • Cupping: The metaphyseal ends of bones become cup-shaped.
    • Splaying: An increase in the width of the metaphyseal ends.
    • Flaring: The ends of the bones point outward.

 

 

  • These characteristics are critical diagnostic features of rickets and help differentiate it from other bone disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to issues like night blindness and impaired immunity.

 

Option B. Vitamin B: B vitamins are crucial for energy production and neurological function. 

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which presents with symptoms like bleeding gums and joint pain. In vitamin C deficiency, the bony ends appear more white on radiographs (Whitening).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rickets is primarily caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, which leads to characteristic bone deformities such as cupping, splaying, and flaring of the metaphyseal ends.

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.text: You are a global health researcher working on a report assessing the development status of various countries. To classify the countries and compare them, you decide to use the Human Development Index (HDI). You recall that HDI is a commonly utilized measure but seek to clarify its exact components, as presented by organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO). Which of the following correctly identifies the components that make up the HDI? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living 

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels. It consists of three main components:

 

  • Life Expectancy at Birth: Measures the average number of years a newborn is expected to live.
  • Education (Literacy and Mean Years of Schooling): Assesses the average number of years of education received by people ages 25 and older and the expected years of schooling for children entering school.
  • Standard of Living (Gross National Income per capita): Adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).

 

Note -

 

  • HDI values range: 0 to + 1
  • HDI India is 0. 633 (Rank 134 out of 186 countries)
  • Human poverty index [HPI] is complementary to HDI

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A medical student presented with complaints of repeated episodes lasting approximately 30 minutes, characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of an impending heart attack. The patient has experienced these episodes 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, and investigations did not reveal any obvious abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic Disorder

 

The clinical presentation of a medical student with repeated episodes of breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and fear of an impending heart attack, each lasting approximately 30 minutes and occurring 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, with no abnormalities found in investigations, is highly suggestive of Panic Disorder. Panic Disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are abrupt surges of intense fear or discomfort reaching a peak within minutes. The symptoms described, including palpitations, sweating, and hyperventilation, are common during panic attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by persistent and excessive worry about various things, but it does not typically involve the acute, intense episodes of fear or the physical symptoms of a panic attack.

 

Option C. Depression: While depression can have anxiety symptoms and panic attacks, the primary feature is a persistent low mood and loss of interest or pleasure in activities, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Social Phobia: Also known as social anxiety disorder, this involves a significant fear of social or performance situations. The symptoms described do not specifically relate to social or performance situations, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: Identify the condition for which Dohlman’s procedure is used: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Zenker's diverticulum

 

Dohlman's procedure is a surgical technique primarily used to treat Zenker's diverticulum. Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch that forms at the junction of the esophagus and pharynx, causing swallowing difficulties, regurgitation, and aspiration. Dohlman's procedure involves endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to alleviate the obstruction and diverticulum formation. This method is favored for its minimal invasiveness and effectiveness in managing the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is treated with a diverticulectomy, which involves the surgical removal of the diverticulum. This congenital anomaly of the small intestine often presents with bleeding, inflammation, or obstruction.

 

Option C. Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia, a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, is typically treated with laparotomy or laparoscopic surgery and subsequent hernia repair. This condition involves abdominal organs herniating into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm.

 

Option D. Menetrier's disease: Menetrier's disease, a rare disorder characterized by hypertrophic gastric folds and protein-losing gastropathy, does not have a specific surgical procedure for treatment. Management often includes supportive care, protein supplements, and medications such as proton pump inhibitors or cetuximab.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dohlman's procedure is specifically used to treat Zenker's diverticulum by endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to relieve symptoms caused by the diverticulum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been diagnosed with achalasia cardia through esophageal manometry. The manometry results reveal simultaneous, high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, along with spasmodic contractions. What type of achalasia does this patient's presentation correspond among the provided options?(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type III

 

The classification of achalasia into types I, II, and III is based on the Chicago Classification. This system uses high-resolution manometry to categorize esophageal motility disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type III achalasia, also known as spastic achalasia, involves spastic contractions in the distal esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This type is the least common and often requires more aggressive therapy.

questions.text: Inhibitor A and B are: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive and non-competitive

 

Inhibitor A is a competitive inhibitor, and Inhibitor B is a non-competitive inhibitor.

 

  • Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor A): In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This means that increasing the concentration of the substrate can overcome the inhibition. In this scenario, the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the reaction remains unchanged because, at high substrate concentrations, the enzyme can still achieve its maximum rate. However, the apparent affinity of the enzyme for the substrate decreases, leading to an increase in the Michaelis constant (Km). On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the y-axis, which represents no change in Vmax but a change in Km.
  • Non-Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor B): Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an allosteric site rather than the active site, and their binding is not affected by the substrate concentration. As a result, the inhibition cannot be overcome by adding more substrate. Non-competitive inhibition leads to a decrease in the Vmax because the inhibitor reduces the overall number of active enzymes. However, Km remains unchanged because the binding of the inhibitor does not affect the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate. On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, non-competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the x-axis, reflecting no change in Km but a decrease in Vmax.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive and non-competitive: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This binding decreases both Km and Vmax because the inhibitor effectively removes some enzyme-substrate complexes from the reaction. This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A shows characteristics of competitive inhibition, not uncompetitive inhibition.

 

Option C. Non-competitive and uncompetitive: This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A is competitive, not non-competitive, and Inhibitor B is non-competitive, not uncompetitive. Therefore, this combination does not accurately represent the inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B.

 

Option D. Non-competitive and competitive: This option is incorrect because it reverses the correct inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B. Inhibitor A is competitive, while Inhibitor B is non-competitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember that competitive inhibitors increase Km but do not change Vmax, while non-competitive inhibitors decrease Vmax but do not change Km.

questions.text: A software engineer presents to the outpatient department with easy fatigability. He gives a history of sitting in front of the computer for 12 - 14 hours. He consumes a lot of junk food with very less fruits and vegetables. Hb is 9gm/dl and MCV 120 fl. What is the most likely cause of this patient's anemia? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Folic acid deficiency

 

The given laboratory values showing anemia and increased MC are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia.

 

This could be due to a lack of cyanocobalamin or folic acid. The lack of fruits and vegetables in the past suggests folic acid deficiency. (folic acid word derived from foliage-green leafy vegetables)

 

Animal products such as meat, fish, milk, and eggs are good sources of vitamin B12.

 

Green vegetables like lettuce, spinach, asparagus, and broccoli are high in folic acid.

 

In megaloblastic anemia, peripheral blood examination reveals oval macrocytes with anisocytosis and poikilocytosis. MCV is typically greater than 100 fL. (normal value: 80-100 fL). The MCHC is not elevated because most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and appear hyperchromic. The number of reticulocytes is low. Neutrophils are larger than normal and have five or more nuclear lobules, indicating nuclear hyper segmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyanocobalamin deficiency: Although vitamin B12 deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia, the dietary history here suggests folic acid deficiency as the primary cause, given the lack of fruits and vegetables.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic (low MCV), hypochromic anemia, not macrocytic anemia as indicated by the elevated MCV.

 

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis: This is a hemolytic anemia characterized by the presence of spherocytes (spherical red blood cells) and usually presents with a normal or slightly decreased MCV, not the significantly elevated MCV seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of anemia in this patient, given the elevated MCV and dietary habits lacking in fruits and vegetables, is folic acid deficiency. Megaloblastic anemia due to folic acid deficiency presents with macrocytic red blood cells and can be confirmed by dietary history and characteristic blood smear findings.

questions.text: A farmer is on a maize-based diet and develops skin rashes on the face, neck, and hand. Which of the following should be given? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The farmer’s symptoms of skin rashes in sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, and hands are characteristic of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Maize-based diets are deficient in tryptophan, which is necessary for niacin synthesis in the body. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, with the dermatitis presenting as symmetrical, pigmented, and scaly skin rashes. Providing niacin supplementation is the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency causes beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not pellagra. The symptoms of thiamine deficiency are primarily neurological and cardiovascular, not dermatological.

 

Option C. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency leads to visual problems, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, and does not cause skin rashes typical of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to anemia and neurological symptoms, including neuropathy and cognitive disturbances. It does not cause skin rashes or dermatitis associated with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin deficiency in individuals consuming a maize-based diet can lead to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Niacin supplementation is the treatment of choice.

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: A 67 yrs. old male patient visits the emergency department due to rapidly worsening pain and swelling in the genital and perianal regions, with signs of necrotizing infection as shown below upon examination, the patient has a history of alcohol abuse and poorly controlled diabetes, and laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated blood glucose levels. What is the accurate statement about the condition presented by the patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

  • The image and clinical scenario suggest Fournier's gangrene, which is a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection and a surgical emergency.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by mixed bacterial flora, often associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation, or trauma.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene include erythema, swelling, pain, and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions.
  • Correct. Fournier's gangrene involves a mixed infection with both aerobic (oxygen-using) and anaerobic (not oxygen-using) bacteria. The presence of multiple bacterial types contributes to the rapid progression and severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy: Incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is typically used for the treatment of gas gangrene caused by the bacterium Clostridium perfringens. While C. perfringens can sometimes be a part of the mixed bacterial flora in Fournier's gangrene, the condition itself is not specifically gas gangrene, and thus anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed: Incorrect. A bilateral orchidectomy, or the removal of both testes, is not a standard treatment for Fournier's gangrene. Testes are typically spared in Fournier’s gangrene.

 

Option D. Compulsory urinary diversion is performed: Incorrect. While urinary diversion might be considered in some cases where the urethra is compromised or if there's significant involvement of the urogenital structures, it's not a compulsory or routine part of the management of Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a surgical emergency characterized by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacterial infection of the genital and perianal regions, often associated with underlying conditions like diabetes and malnutrition.
  • It requires prompt surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following area gets damaged in Housemaid’s knee? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prepatellar bursa

 

PREPATELLAR BURSA

 

  • Prepatellar bursitis or inflammation of the prepaterllar bursa is called Housemaid’s knee.
  • There is swelling in the front of the knee joint.
  • Prepatellar bursa is a small fluid-filled sac in front of the patella. It provides cushioning and protection.
  • Too much pressure on the bursa produces more fluid to protect the knee. This causes build up of swelling in the knee.
  • Prepatellar bursitis is usually caused by repetitive kneeling (common knee position in housemaids for cleaning hence, named as housemaid’s knee) or sudden blow to the front of the knee due to fall.

 

 

  • It is seen more often in men than women.
  • 80% patients are of age 40-60m years.
  • 1/3rd of prepatellar bursitis are septic and 2/3rd are aseptic.
  • Infectious bursitis emerges more often in children than adults.
  • The bursitis settles down within few weeks by conservative treatment. It rarely require any surgical intervention.
  • Etiology:
    • Repetitive kneeling
    • Sudden force or blow or fall on front of knee
    • Constant friction between skin and patella
    • Coexisting inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or gout
    • Ocassionally, due to a bacterial infection (S.aureus in 80% cases)
  • Clinical features:
    • Swelling in front of the knee
    • Knee pain particularly on moving the knee
    • Difficulty in bending the knee, kneel down, or walk
    • Slight redness, differential warmth, and tenderness over the affected area

 

 

  • If present with infection, pain is associated with fever and chills
     
  • Diagnosis is made through detailed history of onset of symptoms, pattern of pain and effect on lifestyle, and physical examination.
  • It does not require X-ray or MRI or CT scan. They can be done to rule out any fracture or soft tissue injury.
  • If uncertain of infection of bursa, arthrocentesis can be done.
  • Treatment:
    • PRICE regimen in initial 72 hours after the injury or when the first sign of inflammation appears, to reduce pain and swelling
    • NSAIDs, topical medications
    • Stretching exercises
    • If swelling is increased, fluid aspiration with needle is done
    • Cortisone injection into the bursa
    • Antibiotic treatment if cause is an infection
    • Arthroscopic bursectomy or excision of bursa, if all treatment methods fail

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapatellar bursa. Suprapatellar bursitis causes pain and swelling just above the knee joint. It is also called as quadriceps tendon bursitis. It may be caused from repetitive overuse in sports, frequent kneeling, injury, coexisting medical condition, or tightness in the quadriceps muscle.

 

 

Option C. Infrapatellar bursa. Also called as Clergyman’s knee, infrapatellar bursitis causes pain just below the patella. It can be caused from frequent kneeling or crawling; overuse activities like running, jumping, kicking, climbing stairs; injury to the knee; secondary to patellar tendonitis and Osgood Schlatters disease; infection.

 

 

Option D. Pes anserine bursa. Pes anserine bursitis, also called intertendinous bursa, is the inflammation of the bursa of the conjoined insertion of Sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus (Pes anserinus). The pain due to this bursitis occurs on the inside of the knee, mostly during running or climbing up the stairs. There may be a spontaneous anteromedial knee pain on walking up or down the stairs. There is swelling and tenderness around the affected bursa; decreased ROM also.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Housemaid’s knee is caused by the inflammation in the prepatellar bursa. It causes pain in the front of the knee.
  • Inflammation in other bursa of the knee causes pain above, below or anteromedial to the knee.

questions.text: A biopsy was taken from the lymph node. What is name of the cell found in the lymph node? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RS cell

 

In the given image Reed-Sternberg cells are seen, which is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Reed-Sternberg cells marker -

  • CDI5
  • CD30 (most sensitive)
  • PAX-5 (most SPECIFIC)

 

RS cells are large and either multi-nucleated or have a bilobed nucleus which resemble as "owl's eye"

 

Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are large, abnormal lymphocytes that are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). There are four main types of HL, each with a different pattern of RS cell morphology.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mott cell: These are plasma cells containing multiple globules of immunoglobulin and are not associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option C. Popcorn cell: This is a variant of RS cells seen in NLPHL, not the classic type shown in the image.

 

Option D. Plasma cell: These are antibody-producing cells derived from B-lymphocytes, not the characteristic cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, identifiable by their "owl's eye" appearance, are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma and can be identified using markers like CD15, CD30, and PAX-5.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to estimate the effect of a drug ‘D’ in three different groups – Plants, Animals, and Human beings. Samples were chosen randomly out of the three groups individually. This is a type of? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Stratified random sampling

 

Stratified random sampling is a sampling method where the total population is divided into homogeneous subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics, and then random samples are taken from each stratum. In this question, the total population consists of three different groups: plants, animals, and humans, each forming a distinct stratum. After forming these strata, random sampling is conducted within each group to select samples, ensuring representation from all subgroups.

 

This approach ensures that the study includes balanced and proportional representation of each group, reflecting the actual composition of the population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random sampling: Simple random sampling involves selecting individuals purely by chance from the entire population without dividing it into subgroups. In this scenario, samples are taken from specific groups rather than randomly from the entire population.

 

Option B. Systematic random sampling: This method involves selecting samples from a population at regular intervals (e.g., every nth member). This technique is not used here as the sampling is done within defined groups, not systematically across the whole population.

 

Option D. Cluster random sampling: In cluster sampling, the population is divided into clusters (often geographically or by natural grouping), and entire clusters are randomly selected for study. In this question, the groups (plants, animals, humans) are not clusters but strata, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stratified random sampling involves dividing a heterogeneous population into homogeneous subgroups and then conducting random sampling within each subgroup.

questions.text: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chorioretinitis

 

  • The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis.
  • Congenital toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii that occurs when a pregnant woman becomes infected and passes the infection on to her developing fetus. The severity of the infection can vary depending on the timing of the infection during pregnancy and the degree of immune response mounted by the fetus.
  • It is acquired perorally from ingesting food that contains oocysts; transplacentally, during vaginal delivery; or rarely, parenterally.
  • Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, occurring in up to 80% of affected infants. It is a type of eye inflammation that affects the retina and can lead to vision impairment or blindness if left untreated.
  • Other common manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis include hydrocephalus (accumulation of fluid in the brain), hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), but these are less common than chorioretinitis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrocephalus: Accumulation of fluid in the brain can occur in congenital toxoplasmosis but is less common than chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is another possible manifestation but not as common as chorioretinitis.

 

Option D. Thrombocytopenia: Low platelet count can occur but is less common compared to chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, affecting up to 80% of infected infants and potentially leading to vision impairment or blindness.

questions.text:
Which of these are the components of high-quality CPR? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a) Compression rate 100-120/min

b) Depth of compression in adults is 3-4 cm

c) Ventilation of 2 breaths for every 30 compressions

d) Allow complete chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, c & d

 

High-quality CPR in adults requires several critical components to be effective. These include:

 

a. Compression Rate: The compression rate should be between 100-120 compressions per minute. This rate is optimal to maintain blood flow during cardiac arrest.

 

b. Depth of Compression: For adults, the correct depth of compression is at least 2 inches (approximately 5 cm). The depth mentioned in the option B (3-4 cm) is incorrect as it is insufficient to generate adequate blood flow.

 

c. Ventilation: The recommended ventilation ratio is 2 breaths for every 30 compressions if no advanced airway is in place. This ensures adequate oxygenation during CPR.

 

d. Chest Recoil: Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression is essential. This allows the heart to refill with blood between compressions, which is crucial for effective circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For high-quality CPR in adults, ensure a compression rate of 100-120/min, a compression depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm), a ventilation ratio of 30:2, and allow complete chest recoil between compressions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was initially being treated with sertraline, but his symptoms were not adequately controlled. His medication regimen was changed to include an MAO inhibitor and amitriptyline. Shortly after the change in medication, the patient developed agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyproheptadine

 

This patient has developed serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur when medications that increase serotonin levels, such as an SSRI (sertraline) combined with an MAO inhibitor and a tricyclic antidepressant (amitriptyline), are used together. The excessive serotonin activity in the central nervous system leads to (serotonin syndrome) symptoms like agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors.

 

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with strong serotonin antagonistic properties and is used as the treatment of choice in serotonin syndrome. It helps to counteract the excess serotonin and alleviate the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lorazepam: While lorazepam can help control seizures associated with serotonin syndrome, it does not address the underlying cause, which is the excess serotonin. Therefore, it is not the most appropriate treatment on its own.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: L-carnitine is used in cases of valproate-induced hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia. It has no role in treating serotonin syndrome.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is used to counteract the toxic effects of methotrexate and has no relevance in the management of serotonin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment for serotonin syndrome: Cyproheptadine, a serotonin antagonist; Ketanserin

choices.text: Lunate at place while others dislocate
Lunate is displaced while other are at place
Lunate is displaced volarly while carpus dislocate dorsally

questions.text: Perilunate dislocation is defined as:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lunate at place while others dislocate

 

WRIST DISLOCATION

 

 

A. Normal; B. Lunate dislocation; C. Perilunate dislocation; D. Normal

 

1. Lunate dislocation

 

  • Lunate dislocates anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position

 

 

A. Pie sign; B. Spilled tea pot sign

 

2. Perilunate dislocation

 

  • Lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally.
  • Perilunate dislocation is more common
  • Most common type: Trans-scaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation
  • Complications: AVN, osteoarthritis and median nerve injury
  • Median nerve is most commonly injured nerve
  • The most commonly used method for closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Lunate is displaced while other are at place. This occurs in lunate dislocation.

 

Option C. Capitate dislocates volarly. This is rarely seen. There is dislocation of distal end of capitate at the capitate-metacarpal joint. It involves disruption of the joint and the intercarpal ligaments of the distal carpal row and minimally displaced fracture of trapezoid. This type of injury can be missed during the evaluation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Perilunate dislocation is defined as the dislocation of all carpal bones except for the lunate, which remains at its place.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Extravasation into venous system
﻿﻿﻿Bilateral cornual block

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

 

The given HSG (hysterosalpingogram) film shows bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes, suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx. Hydrosalpinx is typically caused by the end result of repeated mild endo-salpingitis (inflammation of the fallopian tubes) by pyogenic organisms of low virulence but highly irritant.

 

The organisms involved include:

 

  • Staphylococcus
  • E. coli
  • Gonococcus
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

During the initial infection, the fimbriae become edematous and in-drawn with the serous surface, adhering together to produce closure of the abdominal ostium. The uterine ostium gets closed by congestion. This results in the secretion being pent up, causing the tube to distend. The distension is marked more in the ampullary region than in the more rigid isthmus. As the mesosalpinx is fixed, the resultant distension makes the tube curled and look 'retort'-shaped. The wall is smooth and shiny, containing clear fluid inside, which is usually sterile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extravasation into venous system: This would show contrast leaking into the venous system and not confined to the Fallopian tubes.

 

Option C. Normal HSG: A normal HSG would show patent Fallopian tubes without distension or blockage.

 

Option D. Bilateral cornual block: This would show blockage at the cornua (the point where the Fallopian tubes enter the uterine cavity) without the dilated, fluid-filled appearance seen in hydrosalpinx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrosalpinx is characterized by bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes filled with clear fluid, often due to repeated mild infections causing obstruction and distension.

 

Ref: Page no 171, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Mt. Fuji sign is seen in: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumocephalus

 

The Mt. Fuji sign is a radiological sign seen in cases of tension pneumocephalus. Pneumocephalus refers to the presence of air within the cranial cavity. This condition often arises due to trauma, surgical procedures, or infections that introduce air into the intracranial space. The Mt. Fuji sign specifically indicates tension pneumocephalus, where the accumulated air exerts pressure on the brain structures.

 

 

In the Mt. Fuji sign, the frontal lobes of the brain appear to peak sharply, resembling the shape of Mount Fuji. This appearance is due to the air pressure causing the brain to be compressed and elevated at specific points. This sign is crucial for diagnosing tension pneumocephalus because it suggests that the brain is under significant pressure, which can lead to severe complications if not promptly addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumomediastinum: This condition involves the presence of air in the mediastinum. It is not associated with the Mt. Fuji sign.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, typically due to gastrointestinal perforation or surgical procedures. It does not present with the Mt. Fuji sign.

 

Option D. Pneumothorax: This condition involves the presence of air in the pleural cavity, causing lung collapse. It is unrelated to the Mt. Fuji sign seen in pneumocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mt. Fuji sign is indicative of tension pneumocephalus and is characterized by the peaking of the frontal lobes due to intracranial air pressure.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Factor X inhibitor

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that functions as a direct Factor Xa inhibitor. Factor Xa plays a crucial role in the coagulation cascade, leading to the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, which subsequently forms fibrin clots. By inhibiting Factor Xa, Rivaroxaban effectively prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent clot formation, providing anticoagulant effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Direct Thrombin inhibitor: Drugs that act as direct thrombin inhibitors include Dabigatran, Argatroban, Bivalirudin, and Lepirudin. These drugs directly inhibit thrombin, preventing the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Option C. Increased ATIII activity: This mechanism is associated with heparins and heparinoids. These drugs enhance the activity of antithrombin III (ATIII), which inactivates thrombin and other proteases involved in blood clotting.

 

Option D. Vitamin K inhibition: Warfarin and other coumarin derivatives inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X) by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase. This reduces the body's ability to form clots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is a direct Factor Xa inhibitor, which prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent clot formation in the coagulation cascade.

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.text: The dead body of a 4-year-old child who was playing around the riverside and accidentally drowned in the river is recovered. There is frothing seen from his mouth and nose. Which of the below postmortem findings is not seen in a case of drowning? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to antemortem drowning.

 

This finding is unrelated to drowning and would suggest chronic arsenic poisoning rather than an acute drowning incident.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway
  • Water in the stomach and small intestine
  • Water in middle ear
  • Cerebral edema
  • Bloated and cyanosed face
  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.
  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs
  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils
  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours
  • Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist 
  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voluminous and ballooned out lungs: Seen in drowning due to the inhalation of water.

 

Option C. Paltauf's hemorrhage in sub pleura: Hemorrhages found beneath the pleura, associated with drowning.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist: Indicates a struggle and is a sign of antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of drowning, typical findings include frothing from the mouth and nose, voluminous lungs, and cadaveric spasm with debris. High arsenic concentration in hair shafts is not associated with drowning.

choices.text: Iron prophylaxis is given for 6 months antepartum and 6 months postpartum
Iron prophylaxis is started at 14 weeks and continued for 6 weeks after delivery
Iron prophylaxis starts in the 1st trimester and continues till 6 weeks postpartum
Iron prophylaxis is given 6 months antepartum and 3 months postpartum

questions.text: As per Anemia Mukt Bharat, which is the correct statement regarding iron prophylaxis in pregnant women? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron prophylaxis is given for 6 months antepartum and 6 months postpartum

 

Explanation:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) initiative outlines that iron prophylaxis for pregnant women should start from the 14th week of pregnancy and continue throughout the pregnancy (approximately 6 months) and for 6 months postpartum. The recommended dosage is one red-colored, sugar-coated tablet containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 0.5 mg of folic acid daily. This regimen helps in preventing iron deficiency anemia and folate deficiency anemia during and after pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron prophylaxis for pregnant women under the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative is given from 14 weeks of pregnancy and continues for 6 months postpartum.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

This was an atypical question, which is important only if it is repeated in a subsequent exam.

 

The most likely cause in the following case is Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) - Diffuse Large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) type.

 

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of NHL.

 

The median patient age is about 60 years, but DLBCL also occurs in young adults and children.

 

DLBCL commonly presents with enlarged lymph nodes or rapidly growing mass along with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The B symptoms can be seen in 30% of the patients. Bone marrow involvement is more common in indolent disease and can be seen in up to 50% of the cases.

 

About 50% of the patients have extranodal involvement like stomach or gastrointestinal tract (most common primary extranodal site), skin, bones, spinal cord, testicles, among other locations. Renal involvement can be secondary to bulky disease or lymphadenopathy, causing a ureteral obstruction or due to tumor lysis syndrome. DLBCL can also present with symptoms suggestive of superior vena cava syndrome, compression of the airways. The symptoms can be related to the infiltrated organ if the disease spreads beyond the lymphatics in so-called extranodal disease. A variety of paraneoplastic syndromes may also be associated with B cell lymphomas.

 

Metastasis involves the central nervous system (CNS), skin, contralateral testis, and pleura resulting in local complications.

 

Even though ataxia is seen as a paraneoplastic symptom due to cerebellar degeneration in Hodgkin lymphoma, testicular involvement is very rare and so far, only 5 cases have been reported. Hodgkin lymphoma arises in a single node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. The extranodal presentation is rare. The extranodal disease can occur at any site like lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow is most common if it occurs. The central nervous system and the testis are exceptionally rare sites for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Thus Hodgkin's lymphoma can be ruled out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glioblastoma multiforme: Most common sites are the frontal and temporal lobes. Extracranial metastases of malignant gliomas are extremely rare due to absence of a lymphatic system in the brain and spinal cord for systemic dissemination, dense dura around intracranial veins and lack of nurturing stroma in other organs.

 

 

Option B. Hodgkin’s Lymphoma: Doesn’t involve the extra nodal sites

 

Option D. Non-seminomatous germ cell tumor: These tumors primarily metastasize to the lungs, liver, CNS, and bone, in order of frequency. Although CNS involvement can occur, it is relatively rare. The combination of scrotal swelling and ataxia is less typical for non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), particularly Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), is a likely cause of scrotal swelling and ataxia due to its potential for extranodal involvement and associated paraneoplastic syndromes.

questions.text: Amongst the poisons given below, which poison can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arsenic

 

Arsenic gets fixed to the bones and gets released from it very slowly over a period of time and thus can be detected in the bones for several years after death.

 

Toxicokinetic of Arsenic:

 

  1. Because of short half-life of arsenic in the blood, arsenic is rapidly cleared from the blood. Hence it is less reliable to detect arsenic poisoning.
  2. After clearing from blood, arsenic gets deposited in almost all the tissues where it is found for prolonged period. However, arsenic does not cross blood brain barrier.
  3. Highest concentration is found in liver (followed by kidney)
  4. Urine becomes positive within 6 hours of poisoning and may continue to be positive for about 2-3 weeks. Urine is better than blood to detect arsenic poisoning.
  5. Arsenic also gets deposited in hair, nails, skin and bones where it remains for a much more prolonged time (even for years) after exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin in the blood but does not leave detectable residues in skeletal remains.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulphide: Hydrogen sulphide is a gas that affects soft tissues and is not detected in skeletal remains.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus can affect soft tissues but is not typically detected in bones long after death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arsenic can be found in skeletal remains for several years after death due to its strong binding to the bone matrix and slow release over time.

questions.text: Identify the air cell marked with red arrow in the CT scan of the nose and paranasal sinus: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulla Ethmoidalis

 

The red arrow in the CT scan points to a large air cell within the ethmoid sinus, which is the Bulla Ethmoidalis. The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus. It is centrally located within the ethmoid labyrinth and serves as a key landmark in endoscopic sinus surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Agger Nasi Cell: The Agger Nasi cell is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell, situated anteriorly and superiorly to the insertion of the middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Haller Cell: Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit. They are located inferiorly, near the orbit floor.

 

 

Option D. Onodi Cell: The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends into the sphenoid bone and is situated near the optic nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus.

questions.text: A physician wanted to perform plasma glucose estimation using the vacutainer shown in the image. Which of the following is the anticoagulant used for this test? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Potassium oxalate

 

  • Potassium oxalate is commonly used in vacutainers for plasma glucose estimation because it acts as both an anticoagulant and it prevents clotting by binding calcium in the blood. We presume that the examiner by mistake showed the blue topped vacutainer in place of the gray one. However let us review that blue-topped vacutainer contains Trisodium citrate while the gray-topped vacutainer contains Potassium oxalate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisodium Citrate: Used primarily as an anticoagulant in blood collection tubes for coagulation studies, not suitable for glucose estimation because it does not prevent glycolysis effectively.

 

Option C. Sodium fluoride: Also a glycolysis inhibitor and commonly used with an anticoagulant (potassium oxalate) in glucose testing..

 

Option D. EDTA: Mainly used as an anticoagulant in hematology tests. While it effectively prevents blood clots, it does not inhibit glycolysis, making it unsuitable for glucose tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For accurate plasma glucose estimation, potassium oxalate and enolase is used because it effectively prevents blood clotting and preserves glucose by inhibiting glycolysis respectively. 

 

Always use a grey-top tube (NaF/KOx) when measuring plasma glucose to prevent post-collection glycolysis and falsely low results.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for the same since a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea, and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

The drug that is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects is amiodarone.

 

Amiodarone

 

→ Longest acting [t1/2 → > 3 weeks] anti-arrhythmic drug

 

→ MOA →

  1. Na+ channel Blocker
  2. β-Blocker (Non-competitive)
  3. K+ channel Blocker [Main action]
  4. Calcium channel blocker

 

→ Indicated in all arrhythmias except Torsades de pointes

 

→ Adverse effect of amiodarone:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a Selective Beta 1 Blocker. C/I in Bradycardia, AV Block and Acute CHF. It is used in HTN, Classical angina, MI, Chronic CHF, Arrythmia

 

Option C. Aspirin: Aspirin is only irreversible COX Inhibitor, anti-platelet drug. C/I in child with viral infection (Due to Reye’s syndrome). Can cause Hyperuricemia at therapeutic doses - avoid in gout

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is classified under potassium-sparing diuretic. Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains the body's potassium levels. C/I in patients with hyperkalemia. Can cause gynecomastia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is associated with a range of serious side effects, including pulmonary fibrosis, thyroid dysfunction, liver toxicity, and photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paralytic squint

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

 

Paralytic Squint:

  • Caused by paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles due to nerve damage or muscle pathology.
  • Secondary deviation (movement of the non-paralyzed eye when the paralyzed eye is fixating) is greater than primary deviation.
  • The forced duction test is negative, indicating no mechanical restriction.
  • Patients may experience diplopia and adopt a compensatory head posture to minimize double vision.

 

Additional Information

 

The squint may be either concomitant or incomitant.

• Concomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes.

• Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes.

 

 

FORCED DUCTION TEST:

 

  • Performed to differentiate between the incomitant squint due to paralysis of extraocular muscle and that due to mechanical restriction of the ocular movements.
  • FDT is positive (resistance encountered during passive rotation) in cases of incomitant squint due to mechanical restriction.
  • FDT is negative in cases of extraocular muscle palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concomitant Squint:

  • The angle of deviation is the same in all directions of gaze.
  • Commonly seen in childhood and associated with hereditary factors, uncorrected refractive errors, or perinatal injury.
  • Diplopia is typically absent because the brain suppresses the image from the deviating eye.

 

Option B.  Restrictive Squint:

  • Caused by mechanical restriction of the extraocular muscles due to conditions like thyroid eye disease, trauma, or fibrosis.
  • The forced duction test is positive, indicating resistance during passive eye movement due to mechanical restriction.
  • Diplopia is often present, and the degree of deviation varies depending on the direction of gaze.

 

Option D.  Pseudosquint:

  • An apparent squint where there is no actual misalignment of the eyes.
  • Commonly due to facial anatomical features such as epicanthal folds or a wide nasal bridge.
  • No actual deviation is present, and there are no associated symptoms like diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paralytic squint is characterized by secondary deviation greater than primary deviation and a negative forced duction test, indicating the absence of mechanical restriction.

questions.text: A 24y woman presents with suspected ovarian torsion. What is the investigation of choice? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ultrasound + Color Doppler

 

Ultrasound combined with Color Doppler is the investigation of choice for suspected ovarian torsion.

 

 

This combination is highly effective in identifying the condition. When a patient presents with symptoms of severe abdominal pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting, which is not relieved by analgesics, ovarian torsion should be considered, particularly if an adnexal mass is present. On the ultrasound with Color Doppler, the characteristic "whirlpool sign" can be observed, indicating twisted ovarian vessels and confirming the diagnosis.

 

The use of Color Doppler helps in assessing the blood flow to the ovary. In cases of torsion, blood flow may be absent, leading to ovarian ischemia. A laparoscopy can further confirm the diagnosis, revealing a twisted ovarian pedicle and a necrotic ovary if the torsion is prolonged. Treatment involves laparoscopic detorsion, where the twisted ovary is untwisted. If blood flow returns, a cystectomy may be performed to remove any cysts. If the ovary remains necrotic, an ovariectomy may be necessary to remove the affected ovary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound + Xray: While an ultrasound is useful, an Xray does not provide additional value in diagnosing ovarian torsion. X-rays are not effective in visualizing soft tissues or blood flow.

 

Option C. Ultrasound + DSA: Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is more invasive and not typically used for diagnosing ovarian torsion. It is mainly used for detailed vascular imaging.

 

Option D. MRI: MRI can provide detailed images but is not the first-line investigation due to its higher cost and limited availability compared to ultrasound with Color Doppler.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for suspected ovarian torsion is an ultrasound combined with Color Doppler, which helps visualize the characteristic whirlpool sign and assess blood flow to the ovary.

questions.text: A high dose of folic acid should be given pre-conceptionally in women with? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Poorly controlled diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

A high dose of folic acid is recommended pre-conceptionally for women who are at a higher risk of neural tube defects. This includes women with poorly controlled diabetes, which is associated with an increased risk of congenital abnormalities, including neural tube defects. A high dose of folic acid (4 to 5 mg daily) should be started at least three months before conception to reduce this risk and to be given till 16 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Previous h/o preeclampsia: The preventive strategy for women with a history of preeclampsia includes the use of low-dose aspirin (Ecosprin), not high-dose folic acid.

 

Option B. Previous preterm delivery: Management includes progesterone supplementation or considering a cervical cerclage in cases of cervical insufficiency, rather than high-dose folic acid.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: While folic acid is important in hemoglobinopathies, the primary concern in sickle cell anemia is maintaining adequate folic acid levels due to increased hemolysis, but it is not specifically indicated at high doses for pre-conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Women with poorly controlled diabetes, epileptics, should receive a high dose of folic acid pre-conceptionally to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.
